head.title: Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. - Page #24

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #24 of 71 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Mackintosh, Alexander. Schooner Nancy, Log and Lists of Provisions, 1811-1813. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0039

div.p: Remarks & occurrences on Boars the Nancy Hired Transport on her return passage to Makinac or St Josephs in the month of October 1813[.]

descried the land on our lee distant about 12 miles, which, from the appearance, & our lying too for 16 hours with our starboard tacks aboard I naturally supposed was the land between the point of Bark & Saquina , it was now blowing as fresh as it had at any time, from the Westward between 2 & 3 PM, we bore up & steered ENE keeping sight of the land at intervals for it was now almost one continual squall of snow, at 4 finding we neared the land hauled up NE & NNE, still in hopes of its being the above land at 5 the land still appearing on our lee bow I hove too under the jibb & double reefed main sail, wind was now at WSW the vessel heading NNW & making very good weather 'though a tremendious sea running, a dismal looking night frequent squalls of snow the gale continuing as hard as at its commencement[.] at

First part of this 24 hours just as the watch was called, I gave directions to Jacob Hammond the mate to keep a particular lookout for that at times the moon when observed gave the Horizon very much the appearance of land – at that as the moon shone it would disappear, immeadiately after this he jump up in the boat & was positive of its being the land which we had all along seen I immeadiately ordered the lead to be hove when to our great surprise we found ourselves in 14 fathom water – both anchors were immeadiately let go got ready, but before we could get them off the bows were in 7½ fathom, they were then immediately let go, when after giving her the whole of the cables nearly she brought, we then took in sail & handed them, clinched the best & small bower round the main mast, chocked up the windlass from the deck & between the fore mast & windlass bit when had already canted about 3 Inches – the vessel pitching bows in – & blowing of any thing more violent than ever[.]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
